DESCRIPTION.comments: First Checklist version for Wingstop ---compiled by Ben 28Sep2022

questions.title: All cold hold products and equipment on the line must be held at a temperature of 40°F /5°C or below. Cold foods that require time/temperature control for safety (TCS) are maintained at 40°F /4°C or below in all cold-holding devices including reach-in refrigerated units, cold-top storage devices and ice wells. Cold TCS foods are properly handled, at proper temperature before being displayed and not left out of temperature-controlled environments for extended periods of time.

Cold foods that require time/temperature control for safety (TCS) are maintained at 40°F /4°C or below in all cold-holding devices including reach-in refrigerated units, cold-top storage devices and ice wells. Cold TCS foods are properly handled, at proper temperature before being displayed and not left out of temperature-controlled environments for extended periods of time.

questions.title: Foods that require time/temperature control for safety (TCS) must be cooked/held to minimum poultry standard (food that is undercooked, raw or falls into the temperature danger zone should ever be served to a guest). Foods that require time/temperature control for safety (TCS) are cooked to proper internal temperatures: raw poultry to 165°F/73°C. Foods prepped on site are reheated to 165°F/73°C within 2 hours for hot holding. Foods from a sealed commercial package are reheated to 140°F/60°C for hot holding.
questions.title_esp: Foods that require time/temperature control for safety (TCS) must be cooked/held to minimum poultry standard (food that is undercooked, raw or falls into the temperature danger zone should ever be served to a guest). Foods that require time/temperature control for safety (TCS) are cooked to proper internal temperatures: raw poultry to 165°F/73°C. Foods prepped on site are reheated to 165°F/73°C within 2 hours for hot holding. Foods from a sealed commercial package are reheated to 140°F/60°C for hot holding.

questions.title: Foods are not contaminated. Foods and food-contact surfaces are protected from potential microbiological, physical and chemical hazards. Examples of such hazards include but are not limited to: raw animal products above ready-to-eat foods, commingling raw animal species, thumbtacks, chemicals, medicines or first aid supplies stored above food or food-contact surfaces. When tasting food during preparation, utensils are used only once.
